answer_html: \(\int\sqrt{1 + e^{x}}\, dx=2\sqrt{1 + e^{x}} - \ln|\sqrt{1 + e^{x}}+1| + \ln|\sqrt{1+e^{x}}-1| + C\) completing the question.
answer_latex: $\int\sqrt{1 + e^{x}}\, dx=2\sqrt{1 + e^{x}} - \ln|\sqrt{1 + e^{x}}+1| + \ln|\sqrt{1+e^{x}}-1| + C$ completing the question.
hints_html:
Try a substitution first.

Try the substitution

\(u = \sqrt{1 + e^{x}}\)

Then run through the partial fractions argument. It might help simplify things to notice that

\(2u^{2} = 2u^{2}-2+2\)

Don’t forget to plug back in for x and your +C
hints_latex:
Then run through the partial fractions argument. It might help simplify
things to notice that

$2u^{2} = 2u^{2}-2+2$
Don't forget to plug back in for \emph{x} and your \emph{+C}
hints_raw:
Try a substitution first.
Try the substitution

<math>
u = \sqrt{1 + e^{x}}
</math>
Then run through the partial fractions argument. It might help simplify things to notice that

<math>
2u^{2} = 2u^{2}-2+2
</math>
Don't forget to plug back in for ''x'' and your ''+C''
question: 4 (b)
sols_html:
Following the hint, we start off by setting

\(u = \sqrt{1 + e^{x}}\)

Then we have that

\(\displaystyle u^{2}-1 = e^{x}\)

and more importantly that

\(du = \frac{e^{x}}{2\sqrt{1 + e^{x}}}\, dx = \frac{u^{2}-1}{2u}\, dx\)

Thus, substituting these values in yield

\(\int\sqrt{1 + e^{x}}\, dx = \int u \left(\frac{2u}{u^{2}-1} \, du \right) = \int \frac{2u^{2}}{u^{2}-1} \, du\)

Via the third hint, we can simplify this last integral to

\(\int \frac{2u^{2}}{u^{2}-1} \, du = \int \frac{2u^{2}-2+2}{u^{2}-1} \, du = \int 2\, du + \int \frac{2}{u^{2}-1} \, du\)

(one could find this expression by explicitly doing the long division though on an exam you probably want to try to save some time). The first integral is

\(\int 2\, du = 2u = 2\sqrt{1 + e^{x}}\)

(we’ll add the constant in later) and the second integral we evaluate by partial fractions.

\(\frac{2}{u^{2}-1} = \frac{2}{(u+1)(u-1)} = \frac{A}{u+1} + \frac{B}{u-1} = \frac{A(u-1) + B(u+1)}{(u+1)(u-1)}\)

This gives the expression

\(\displaystyle 2 = A(u-1) + B(u+1)\)

Plugging in \(u=1\) yields

\(\displaystyle 2 = A(1-1) + B(1+1) = 2B\)

and so \(B=1\). Plugging in \(u = -1\) yields

\(\displaystyle 2 = A((-1)-1) + B((-1)+1) = -2A\)

and so \(A = -1\). Hence

\(\int \frac{2}{u^{2}-1} \, du = \int -\frac{1}{u+1} \, du + \int \frac{1}{u-1} \, du = -\ln|u+1| + \ln|u-1|\)

(we’ll add the constant in later). Hence, applying everything, we have

\[\begin{aligned} \int\sqrt{1 + e^{x}}\, dx &= \int \frac{2u^{2}}{u^{2}-1} \, du \\ &= \int 2\, du + \int \frac{2}{u^{2}-1} \, du \\ &= 2u -\ln|u+1| + \ln|u-1| + C \\ &= 2\sqrt{1 + e^{x}} - \ln|\sqrt{1 + e^{x}}+1| + \ln|\sqrt{1+e^{x}}-1| + C\end{aligned}\]

completing the question.
sols_latex:
Following the hint, we start off by setting

$u = \sqrt{1 + e^{x}}$

Then we have that

$\displaystyle u^{2}-1 = e^{x}$

and more importantly that

$du = \frac{e^{x}}{2\sqrt{1 + e^{x}}}\, dx = \frac{u^{2}-1}{2u}\, dx$

Thus, substituting these values in yield

$\int\sqrt{1 + e^{x}}\, dx = \int u \left(\frac{2u}{u^{2}-1} \, du \right) = \int \frac{2u^{2}}{u^{2}-1} \, du$

Via the third hint, we can simplify this last integral to

$\int \frac{2u^{2}}{u^{2}-1} \, du = \int \frac{2u^{2}-2+2}{u^{2}-1} \, du = \int 2\, du +  \int \frac{2}{u^{2}-1} \, du$

(one could find this expression by explicitly doing the long division
though on an exam you probably want to try to save some time). The first
integral is

$\int 2\, du = 2u = 2\sqrt{1 + e^{x}}$

(we'll add the constant in later) and the second integral we evaluate by
partial fractions.

$\frac{2}{u^{2}-1} = \frac{2}{(u+1)(u-1)} = \frac{A}{u+1} + \frac{B}{u-1} = \frac{A(u-1) + B(u+1)}{(u+1)(u-1)}$

This gives the expression

$\displaystyle 2 = A(u-1) + B(u+1)$

Plugging in $u=1$ yields

$\displaystyle 2 = A(1-1) + B(1+1) = 2B$

and so $B=1$. Plugging in $u = -1$ yields

$\displaystyle 2 = A((-1)-1) + B((-1)+1) = -2A$

and so $A = -1$. Hence

$\int \frac{2}{u^{2}-1} \, du = \int -\frac{1}{u+1} \, du + \int \frac{1}{u-1} \, du = -\ln|u+1| + \ln|u-1|$

(we'll add the constant in later). Hence, applying everything, we have

\begin{align*}
\int\sqrt{1 + e^{x}}\, dx &= \int \frac{2u^{2}}{u^{2}-1} \, du \\
&= \int 2\, du +  \int \frac{2}{u^{2}-1} \, du \\
&= 2u -\ln|u+1| + \ln|u-1| + C \\
&= 2\sqrt{1 + e^{x}} - \ln|\sqrt{1 + e^{x}}+1| + \ln|\sqrt{1+e^{x}}-1| + C
\end{align*}

completing the question.
sols_raw:
Following the hint, we start off by setting

<math>
u = \sqrt{1 + e^{x}}
</math>

Then we have that

<math> \displaystyle
u^{2}-1 = e^{x}
</math>

and more importantly that

<math>
du = \frac{e^{x}}{2\sqrt{1 + e^{x}}}\, dx = \frac{u^{2}-1}{2u}\, dx
</math>

Thus, substituting these values in yield

<math>
\int\sqrt{1 + e^{x}}\, dx = \int u \left(\frac{2u}{u^{2}-1} \, du \right) = \int \frac{2u^{2}}{u^{2}-1} \, du
</math>

Via the third hint, we can simplify this last integral to

<math>
\int \frac{2u^{2}}{u^{2}-1} \, du = \int \frac{2u^{2}-2+2}{u^{2}-1} \, du = \int 2\, du +  \int \frac{2}{u^{2}-1} \, du
</math>

(one could find this expression by explicitly doing the long division though on an exam you probably want to try to save some time). The first integral is 

<math>
 \int 2\, du = 2u = 2\sqrt{1 + e^{x}}
</math>

(we'll add the constant in later) and the second integral we evaluate by partial fractions. 

<math>
\frac{2}{u^{2}-1} = \frac{2}{(u+1)(u-1)} = \frac{A}{u+1} + \frac{B}{u-1} = \frac{A(u-1) + B(u+1)}{(u+1)(u-1)}
</math>

This gives the expression

<math> \displaystyle
2 = A(u-1) + B(u+1)
</math>

Plugging in <math> u=1 </math> yields

<math> \displaystyle
2 = A(1-1) + B(1+1) = 2B
</math>

and so <math> B=1 </math>. Plugging in <math> u = -1</math> yields

<math>  \displaystyle
2 = A((-1)-1) + B((-1)+1) = -2A
</math>

and so <math> A = -1 </math>. Hence

<math> 
\int \frac{2}{u^{2}-1} \, du = \int -\frac{1}{u+1} \, du + \int \frac{1}{u-1} \, du = -\ln|u+1| + \ln|u-1|
</math>

(we'll add the constant in later). Hence, applying everything, we have

<math>
\begin{align}
\int\sqrt{1 + e^{x}}\, dx &= \int \frac{2u^{2}}{u^{2}-1} \, du \\
&= \int 2\, du +  \int \frac{2}{u^{2}-1} \, du \\
&= 2u -\ln|u+1| + \ln|u-1| + C \\
&= 2\sqrt{1 + e^{x}} - \ln|\sqrt{1 + e^{x}}+1| + \ln|\sqrt{1+e^{x}}-1| + C
\end{align}
</math>

completing the question.
